title: Architecture Style Selection
description: Choose the right architectural style based on your scalability needs, team structure, deployment constraints, and system characteristics

questions.text: What is your primary architectural driver?
questions.description: What's the most important quality attribute for your system?

options.label: Scalability - Need to handle massive traffic and scale independently
Simplicity - Easy to build, deploy, and maintain
Flexibility - Frequent changes and rapid iteration
Performance - Low latency and high throughput

questions.text: How will different parts of your system scale?

options.label: Different components need to scale independently at different rates
The entire system scales roughly uniformly

questions.text: What is your team's size and structure?

options.label: Small team (1-5 developers) or solo developer
Medium team (5-20 developers), can split into sub-teams
Large organization (20+ developers) with multiple teams

questions.text: How often do you need to deploy changes?

options.label: Multiple times per day - CI/CD with independent deployments
Few times per week - Regular releases
Monthly or less - Stable releases

questions.text: What type of performance is most critical?

options.label: Low latency - Sub-millisecond response times
High throughput - Processing millions of requests
Async processing - Background jobs and event handling

questions.text: How comfortable is your team with distributed systems?

options.label: Expert - Experienced with distributed transactions, eventual consistency
Intermediate - Some experience, willing to learn
Beginner - Prefer simple, straightforward architectures
Cloud-native with Kubernetes/containers and DevOps culture
Cloud platform (AWS/Azure/GCP) with simple deployment
Traditional servers or limited infrastructure

questions.description: Can one component failure bring down the entire system?

options.label: Critical - Components must fail independently
Moderate - Some isolation needed but not critical
Not important - Acceptable for system to fail together

questions.text: Do you need asynchronous processing or event streaming?

options.label: Yes - Core requirement with message queues/event streams
Yes - Some background jobs and async tasks
No - Mostly synchronous request-response

questions.text: What is your data consistency requirement?

options.label: Strong consistency - ACID transactions required
Eventual consistency - Can tolerate temporary inconsistencies
Mixed - Some parts need strong, others can be eventual

microservices.name: Microservices Architecture
microservices.reasoning: Best for large-scale systems that need independent deployment, scaling, and fault isolation. Each service is a separate deployable unit with its own database.
tradeoffs: ✅ Technology diversity - different tech per service
✅ Fault isolation - one service failure doesn't crash all
microservices.whenToReconsider: If your team is small (<5 people), lacks distributed systems experience, or doesn't have mature DevOps practices. Start with a modular monolith instead.
microservices.bestFor: Large organizations (20+ devs), high-scale systems with varied scaling needs, teams experienced with distributed systems and cloud-native deployments

service_based.name: Service-Based Architecture
service_based.reasoning: A middle ground between monolith and microservices. Coarse-grained services (3-12 services) with shared database or federated data. Easier to manage than microservices.
tradeoffs: ✅ Simpler than microservices but still scalable
✅ Can share some data between services
✅ Good fault isolation without extreme complexity
✅ Easier to refactor into microservices later
❌ Not as fine-grained scalability as microservices
service_based.whenToReconsider: If your system is very simple and a monolith would suffice, or if you need extreme scalability that requires full microservices.
service_based.bestFor: Medium-sized teams (5-20 devs), systems that need some scalability but not extreme, good stepping stone from monolith to microservices

event_driven.name: Event-Driven Architecture
event_driven.reasoning: Based on asynchronous events and message passing. Excellent for high-throughput, real-time systems with complex workflows and integrations.
tradeoffs: ✅ Excellent for async workflows and integrations
❌ Eventual consistency - harder to reason about
❌ Difficult to test and troubleshoot flows
event_driven.whenToReconsider: If you need strong consistency, have simple synchronous workflows, or lack experience with message brokers and eventual consistency patterns.
event_driven.bestFor: Systems with heavy async processing, real-time analytics, IoT, integration-heavy systems, teams comfortable with eventual consistency

layered.name: Layered (N-Tier) Architecture
layered.reasoning: Traditional architecture with horizontal layers (presentation, business, persistence, database). Simple, well-understood, and easy to build.
tradeoffs: ❌ Can become tightly coupled over time
layered.whenToReconsider: When you need independent scaling, have multiple teams working on different features, or need to deploy components independently.
layered.bestFor: Small teams (<5 devs), MVPs and startups, CRUD-heavy applications, systems with traditional server infrastructure, learning projects

modular_monolith.name: Modular Monolith
modular_monolith.reasoning: A monolithic deployment but with strong internal module boundaries. Best of both worlds - simplicity of monolith with flexibility to extract services later.
tradeoffs: ✅ Easy to refactor into services later
❌ May need to migrate to services for extreme scale
modular_monolith.whenToReconsider: When you reach extreme scale and need independent deployment, or when you have multiple teams that need complete autonomy.
modular_monolith.bestFor: Startups and growing companies, teams of any size with good engineering discipline, systems that may need to scale but aren't there yet, successor to layered architecture
